canvas-of-ideas.html.title: CANVAS OF IDEAS
canvas-of-ideas.html.description:
Have to check regulations on:Neighborhood scaleHow does the phasing impact the flora and fauna around the plots. How are the neighboring residents affected? How can we limit the inconveniences they face?Urban scalePlot scaleStructural & Architectural imposed limits Reusability of the materials we have. Crane positioning and how we work around that. Leaving paths for construction vehicles ( we can't impede the construction works) What are the regulations on going above a construction site How does the phasing impact the traffic flow around the area (Maria has more insight on this)FoundartionsHelical pile anchorsOne way to use this system is to have concrete slabs acting as footings, along with helical anchors that are added to parts of the foundation that require more load bearing capacity. #Research
#FoundationHelical anchors foundation › **Conclusions **
Ballast Supported FoundationsEdit overview
Helical anchors foundation › **Advantages **Pasted image 20251214190742.png
GEM-STAGE-Factsheet-2021, page 1The GEM-stage tower is a portable tower that is capable to provide the power needed for a full live show of a DJ. It can be fit in a container which can be carried by a semi-truck to the location and assembled there. Study the foundation implementation (precast concrete blocks) Check connections and stability principles Assembly & transportation method Ask about the weathering effects on the steel members/ connections
#Research
Gem-Stage tower (floor)Pasted image 20251214213326.pngCore houses the electronics for the generation of solar energy. We could incorporate something similar if we have functions that require power. This way it doesn't impede the construction sites
Structure uses a very heavy core along with cables that anchor in submerged concrete pads to take horizontal loadingPasted image 20251214214706.png Regulatory Context and Classification The structure's operation within the area covered by the Eindhoven Internationale Knoop XL project requires adherence to the Environment Buildings Decree (Bbl), particularly concerning temporary status and relocation.A. Temporary Structure ClassificationA "temporary structure" is defined as a structure with a maintenance period of no more than 15 years at the same location, making your 3-year plan compliant with this definition.• General Rules: The rules of Chapter 3 (Existing Structures) generally apply to the construction of a temporary structure, unless otherwise specified in Sections 4.2 to 4.7 (New Constructions),. The underlying assumption for structural and health requirements is that satisfying the rules for existing structures (Sections 3.2 to 3.7) is sufficient.• Specific Requirements (Chapter 4): Key rules from Chapter 4 that specifically apply to temporary structures include provisions related to:    ◦ Escape Routes and Fire Assistance: Articles 4.65 to 4.71 (course of escape routes) and Articles 4.84 and 4.85 (fire brigade lift/aid post) apply.    ◦ Ventilation and Flue Gas: The requirements for ventilation/flushing facility capacity (Articles 4.131 and 4.132) and rules regarding flue gas discharge/combustion air supply (Articles 4.135 to 4.141) apply.    ◦ Sustainability (Thermal): Articles 4.152 (thermal resistance), 4.153 (heat transfer coefficient), and 4.154 (air volume flow) apply, generally setting the minimum requirements at values specified in Table 4.148B,.B. Relocation RegulationsThe relocation of a temporary structure is considered the displacement of an existing structure,.• Rules for Displacement: When relocating an existing structure in an unchanged composition, the structure must comply with the rules of Chapter 3 (Existing Structures),. For a temporary structure, this rule remains applicable after relocation,. Structural and Geotechnical Requirements The structure's design must comply with the general design principles found in the Eurocodes, which inform the Bbl regulations.A. Structural Safety and Load CombinationsAll structures must be designed to withstand all forces during use and execution, and to prevent progressive collapse (disproportionate damage in the event of an accident),,.• Verification Basis: Verification of the ultimate limit state (ULS) is based on Eurocode (EN 1990),,,,.• Load Combinations: Structural non-failure verification involves using fundamental load combinations (normal use conditions),, and exceptional load combinations (e.g., resulting from fire, impact, or explosion),,.B. Optimal Foundations (Geotechnical Requirements)While the sources do not specify the single "optimal" foundation type (which depends on local soil conditions and logistics), they mandate the methodology for selecting suitable foundations and verifying their performance.• Geotechnical Design: Design must account for geotechnical aspects (soil, rock, groundwater) in accordance with Eurocode 7 (EN 1997),. Geotechnical investigations are required to establish the ground profile and strength/deformation properties.• Investigation Depth: The investigation depth must extend to all strata that will affect the project. For piles, this depth is typically down to a level below the lowest point of the pile base,.• Bearing Resistance and Settlement: The bearing resistance and settlement of spread foundations may be derived using:    ◦ Semi-empirical or analytical methods from Cone Penetration Test (CPT) results.    ◦ Standard Penetration Test (SPT) or Dynamic Probing (DP) results in coarse soil, provided local experience or reliable correlations are used,Ballasted supported foundationThis type of foundation relies on weight to provide resistance against uplift and lateral forces.
Ballasted systems (non penetrating)- this type of foundation relies solely on weight to resist against forces. The most common materials are concrete blocks, like the system used in Gem-Stage tower (floor). This is the most common method and probably the most cost efficient. Steel baskets filled with agregate, and containers filled with water/concerte are also used. These are best used when penetration is prohibited or impractical (this might be relevant to us depending on what the municipality tells us the construction sites will be). Failure modes-Ground failure, since this foundation doesn't penetrate the ground, it relies on distributing the force over weak soil like mud or peat. Concrete based footings- More traditional approach, this casts or drills piles into the ground for heavy load bearing. This might be a good option provided we can remove the foundation and reuse it again (if the loads call for such heavy foundation elements) Submerged concrete blocks with ballast above. We could have big concrete blocks that are underground at around -1.000mm. The primary failure mode of this method would be shear failure of the slab. This, however can be mitigated by increasing the number of contact points to the ground thus decreasing the load on each one, adding rebar and changing dimensions.
#Research
#Foundation Ballast Supported Foundations
Look into starwin and their developed method (still this might need submerging by -0.500mmIMG-15-12-2025-120629098.pngIMG-15-12-2025-120548680.pngIMG-15-12-2025-120418416.pngPasted image 20251214215500.pngGemini_Generated_Image_hbccjnhbccjnhbcc.png Rules for temporary structures are less strict as we can use the existing building protocols instead of the new construction ones Foundations should be made with precast concrete slabs instead of pouring piles (See Floor project) Load combinations along with 3D wind patterns have to be considered. ( less of an issue if we go for the small wildlife variant as the structures are much smaller) Dynamics of users have to be taken into account> steel doesn't dampen vibrations well and it can cause resonance which weakens the structure Possible limitation of non penetrating systems is that I have mainly found them to be implemented in solar pannel arrays Oslo Opera House TU Delft Library Ewha womans university
4. The High line
#Research Second Ground architectural works
The high linePasted image 20251219005135.pngPasted image 20251219004012.pngPasted image 20251219003844.png

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
